sentences.sentence: Death laughed, and took a cup, and filled it in a pool of water, and out of the cup rose Illness.
Illness passed through the crowd( 人群 ) of men, and when she returned, a third of them lay dead.
When Greed( 贪婪 ) saw this, she beat her chest( 胸膛 ) and cried.
“You have killed a third of my servants. Leave this place.
There is war in the mountains far away, and the kings of each side are calling for you.
What does my valley( 山谷 ) matter to you, and why do you stay in it?
Leave this place, and come back no more.”
“No,” answered Death, “I will not go until you have given me a grain( 粒 ) of corn.”
But Greed( 贪婪 ) closed her hand tightly( 紧紧地 ).
“I will not give you anything,” she said.
Death laughed, picked up( 捡起 ) a black stone, and threw it into the forest.
And then out of the forest came Fever in a robe( 长袍 ) of fire.
Fever passed through the crowd( 人群 ) of men, and touched them, and each man that she touched died.
The grass turned brown under her feet as she walked.
Greed( 贪婪 ) shook, and shouted, “You are cruel( 残忍的 )! People have nothing to eat in the walled cities of Egypt( 埃及，地名 ), and there has been no rain there, and the plants will not grow.
Leave this place, and go to those who need you, and leave me my servants.”
“No,” answered Death, “I will not go until you have given me a grain( 粒 ) of corn.”
“I will not give you anything,” said Greed( 贪婪 ).
Death laughed again, and he whistled( 吹口哨 ) through his fingers.
And then Disease( 疾病 ) came flying through the air.
Disease( 疾病 ) flew over the crowd( 人群 ) of men, and covered them with her wings, and no man was left alive.
Greed( 贪婪 ) ran screaming( 尖叫着 ) through the forest, and Death climbed upon his red horse and rode away, faster than the wind.
The young King cried, and said: “Who were these men, and for what were they searching?”
“For rubies( 红宝石 ) for a king’s crown( 王冠 ),” answered one who stood behind him.
The young King turned around to see a man holding a silver mirror( 镜子 ) in his hand.
He grew pale, and asked: “For what king?”
The man answered: “Look in this mirror( 镜子 ), and you will see him.”
He looked in the mirror( 镜子 ), and saw his own face.
He gave a loud cry and woke up( 醒来 ).
The bright sunlight was shining through his window, and in the trees of the garden he could hear the birds singing.
The young King’s servants and officials came in and bowed( 鞠躬 ) deeply to him.
The servants brought him the robe( 礼袍 ) made of thin gold fabric( 布料 ), and set the crown( 王冠 ) and the scepter( 权杖 ) in front of him.
He looked at the precious( 珍贵的 ) things in front of him.
They were beautiful, more beautiful than anything he had ever seen.
But he remembered his dreams, and he said to his servants: “Take these things away, because I will not wear them.”
The King’s officials were shocked( 震惊的 ), and some of them laughed, because they thought that he was joking.
But he spoke to them again, in a serious voice, and said: “Take these things away, and hide them from me.
Even though today is the day of my coronation( 加冕 ), I will not wear them.
I will not wear my robe( 礼袍 ), because it has been made of pain and sorrow( 悲伤 ).
There is blood in the heart of the ruby( 红宝石 ), and death in the heart of the pearl( 珍珠 ).”
And then he told them about his three dreams.
When his officials heard these dreams, they looked at each other and whispered( 窃窃私语 ), saying:
“Surely he has gone mad, because is a dream not just a dream?
These are not real things, so why should he pay attention to them? And what do we have to do with the lives of those who work for us?
Should a man not eat bread until he has spoken with the man who grew the grain( 谷物 ), nor drink wine till he has talked with the man who grew the grapes?”
One of the King’s officials spoke to the young King, and said,
“My King, I ask that you forget about these dark thoughts of yours, and put on this fine robe( 礼袍 ), and set this crown( 王冠 ) upon your head.
For how will the people know that you are a king, if you do not dress like a king?”
The young King looked at him.
“Will they not know I am the king, if I do not dress like one?” he asked.
“They will not know you, my King,” cried the official.
“I had thought that some men were king-like,” he answered, “but you may be right.
And yet I will not wear this robe( 礼袍 ), or this crown( 王冠 ).
Instead I will go dressed in the clothes that I wore when I first came to this palace.”
And then he ordered them all to leave him, except for one servant, who was a boy about the same age as him.
